Background 
 
1. The term ‘Foreign Students’ is used at NUST on Qalam and in other 
communications refers to students enrolled through SAT-based admissions, which may 
also include some national candidates. To prevent confusion, the term ‘International 
Students’ will be specifically used to refer to Non-Pakistani candidates who require visa 
to study in Pakistan. 
2. The current tuition fee for international students for MS & PhD was kept the same 
as that for domestic students which is considerably lower than that of some of our 
competitor universities in other countries. The decision to keep the fee low aimed at 
attracting international students, but the extent to which this adjustment has contributed 
to an increase in international student enrollments remains uncertain. On the other hand,

extent to which this adjustment has contributed to an increase in international student enrollments remains uncertain. On the other hand,

2 
Last Updated On 6 November 2023 
 
the reduced fee may also create a perception among potential international students that 
NUST's programs are of lower quality. 
3. Moreover, many international universities provide bursaries, discounts on fees and 
waive off application processing fee to encourage international enrollments, to develop 
bilateral ties with friendly countries, human resource development of developing 
countries. Scholarships are also used as a marketing tool to attract international 
applicants. Given NUST’s already lower fee, it is challenging to offer additional discounts. 
Keeping above in view, it was needed that tuition fee for Master & PhD program to be 
increased to match those of the top-ranked universities in our competitor countries 
enabling NUST provide substantial discounts and scholarships.

This strategy is expected 
to serve as a potent marketing tool to showcase the value of our programs and attract 
more students. There have been no changes to the international student’ tuition fees for 
undergraduate (UG) programs as the fee was already higher as compared to fee of 
national students. 
4. To increase international student enrollment while keeping the marketing and 
outreach costs low, NUST is exploring the option of offering reward-based referral system 
and collaborating with student recruitment agencies in the targeted countries. 
5. Additionally, International Students who wish to study at NUST often are unable to 
join the semester on time due to delays in visa processing and HEC NOC (No Objection 
Certificate) issues. It is estimated that an overall 05 months are required from the day 
admission letter is issued to the semester start date, regardless of the Fall or Spring 
semester.

As per the current admission timeline which is almost the same for domestic 
students, it is almost impossible for international student to complete pre departure 
formalities (i.e. NOC and Visa etc.) and join the program on time which can lead to 
admission deferment to next semester/next intake or even abandoning admission offer. 
Hence to streamline admission, revision in the timeline was required for international 
students.

manner. UG, MS & PhD applicants will be able to apply in January for the Fall intake and 
receive conditional offer by March while PhD applicants will be able to receive conditional

May and conditional offer letters will be issued in August giving enough time for

the following hindrances in processing of international admissions: 
a. To accommodate applicants for UG programs who are awaiting their 12th 
Grade/A-Level 2nd year results or IBCC equivalency to receive conditional 
offer. 
b.

To accommodate MS program applicants who do not have the GRE Test 
scores available, awaiting degree, awaiting HEC equivalency certificates or 
opting to appear for in person NUST Admission Test. 
c. To accommodate PhD applicants awaiting degree, awaiting HEC equivalency 
certificates or scheduled to clear NUST PhD admission test. 
d. Conditional offer letters will be issued to applicants mentioned in para a- 
c enabling them to receive HEC NOC which is a prerequisite for a student 
visa application. Student will be able to apply for visa and arrive in Pakistan 
timely and complete their program’ eligibility requirement. 
e. In the event that a student obtains a visa or travels to Pakistan however is 
unable to meet any of the conditions outlined in their offer, NUST reserves the 
right to revoke the student's admission offer while keeping HEC and the 
Ministry of Interior informed. 
f.

All concerned departments & schools will be responsible to ensure international 
student admissions are processed as per the revised timeline. 
g. ICT Dte will develop a separate application portal for international students. 
Meanwhile, any admissions application received during the period can be 
handled manually. 
h. The detailed timeline of admission timelines for UG, MS & PhD is attached as 
Annex “A”.

7. Revision in Tuition Fee: This Working Paper proposes increasing the tuition fees 
for PhD & MS for international students. There is no change in fee proposed for UG 
students. The increase is proposed by applying a similar approximate ratio used to 
calculate the fee difference between national and international students in undergraduate 
programs. Despite the varying ratios of 6.28, 5.24, and 4.87 observed for different 
undergraduate programs, it is proposed to round the ratio to 5 for increasing the fee for 
MS and PhD students, compared to the national fee. The proposed revision will also align 
NUST fee with universities of the region. A list of Top ranked universities of NUST 
competitor countries along with their average tuition fees is attached as Annex “B”.

Further details on the comparison of current and revised tuition fee are attached as Annex 
“C”. With the year-on-year change in the rate of US Dollar, the fee may be revised once 
a year to maintain a ratio of 1:5. Typically, the Finance Department (Fin Dte) adjusts fees 
annually between June and July, causing further delays in sending out admission letters. 
As part of this proposal, to streamline the procedure for international students, provisional 
admissions will now be extended in March. Under this plan, the Fin Dte will issue 
projected fee invoices that will be sent to students along with provisional offer letters. 
These invoices will outline expected fee increments for the upcoming admission cycle. 
These invoices will explicitly state that the fees are calculated based on projections and 
are subject to potential revisions.

9. Scholarships: Various scholarships/ fee-remissions options are being proposed 
for UG, MS & PhD students exclusively on tuition fees. 
10.

UG Scholarships: Aligned with the Government the Government of Pakistan's 
commitment to fostering diplomatic ties, and establishing professional connections with 
friendly nations, as well as supporting the development of countries grappling with 
underdevelopment or post-conflict situations, diverse scholarship opportunities for 
undergraduate degree programs—covering only tuition fees—are being proposed 
exclusively for Nationals of these countries. 
11. MS & PhD Scholarships: NUST offers outstanding Masters and PhD degree 
programs renowned for their exceptional academic quality and faculty expertise. The 
university has consistently maintained a uniform tuition fee for both domestic and 
international students, which was substantially lower than the fees charged by many 
competing universities around the world. Wide this WP, revisions in the tuition fees 
structure for international MS and PhD students are proposed, aimed at expanding 
scholarship opportunities.

This strategic adjustment aims to bolster the appeal of NUST's 
programs, thereby attracting a wider pool of prospective applicants. 
12. General Terms & Conditions of Scholarships: 
a. Student scholarships will be applicable for entire degrees as per the 
program requirement. This translates to up to 4 years or 8 regular semesters 
for disciplines such as Engineering, IT, and Social Sciences programs, and 
up to 5 years for Architecture and Law programs etc. Similarly, 2 years for 
MS and 3 years for PhD. 
b.

to 5 years for Architecture and Law programs etc. Similarly, 2 years for MS and 3 years for PhD. b.

c. Scholarship applications will be assessed based on various factors 
including academic profile, financial need, leadership qualities and 
community service etc. 
d. Other mandatory academic and non-academic charges like admission 
processing fee, hostel rent, messing charges, air fare, health facility fee and 
security charges etc. are not covered under these scholarships. 
13. Different discounts and scholarship/ fee-remission options are as follows: 
a. The policy proposes that the application processing fee ($80for UG and ~$9 for 
MS & PhD) may be waived to encourage students to apply. 
b. Various scholarship/ fee-remission options for UG, MS & PhD are being 
proposed, ranging between 25%-100%. 
c. Scholarships of 25% and 50% as an added incentive will be useful for student 
recruiters.

Recruiters will be able to encourage prospective students, as their 
nominated candidates will be guaranteed to receive the scholarship, subject 
eligibility and merit conditions are met. 
d. For new applicants, Fee Remission scholarship that will adjust their fee to be 
equivalent to the tuition fee for national students. Fee Remission offer can be 
advertised on NUST website and offered to new applicants based on their 
academic standing on a case-to-case basis. 
e. Self-sponsored students admitted on full fee will also be eligible for Fee 
Remission Program which will recognize students who have shown exceptional 
academic performance and provide them with the opportunity to continue to 
excel in their studies. Fee Remission will be available to the top 3 international 
students at every school once they have completed their first year. 
f.

100% scholarship on tuition fee will be subject to an assessment of the 
applicant's academic profile by NUST and will only be granted at the discretion 
of NUST leadership on a case-to-case basis. 
g. The scholarship options may be reviewed on a regular basis and changed with 
the approval of the competent authority.

14. Composition of Scholarship Application Review Committee: 
a. Students will submit a 300-400-word personal statement as part of their 
scholarship application highlighting their motivation to study the chosen 
program, career goals, how would the scholarship help in academic & 
professional journey and highlight leadership skills, projects or community 
service work undertaken during study. The scholarship application will be 
submitted through the dedicated application portal of international students. 
b. The Scholarship Application Review Committee shall assess and make 
informed decisions on scholarship applications.

The following is a 
suggested composition for the committee: 
i. Chairman: Pro Rector Academics 
ii. Members: 
1. Registrar 
2. Dir Academics 
3. Dir QA & NIO 
4. Dean/ HoD/ Faculty Representative of the Respective School 
5. Dir UAO 
6. Fin Dte Representative (to provides insights into the budget 
and resource availability for scholarships, helping to align 
decisions with the institution's financial capacity.) 
7. Secretary (DD/ AD NIO) 
c. Responsibilities & criteria for award of scholarship: 
i. Review scholarship applications in accordance with criteria. 
ii. Evaluate academic achievements, motivation towards the chosen 
course, career objectives, impact of scholarship on awardees 
academic and career goals and financial need. 
iii. Consider diversity, inclusivity, and long-term impact on scholarship 
recipients.

15. International Student Recruiters & Reward Based Referral System: 
a. International Student Recruiters. A general commission structure 
ranging between 10%-30% of annual tuition fee will be negotiated with 
student recruiters. Commission will be applicable on first year’ tuition fee 
only. Partner student recruiters can nominate students for various 
programs; however, admissions will be based solely on eligibility and 
existing NUST merit criteria. The terms and commission structure outlined 
in the document serve as general guidelines and align with industry 
standards.

However, they are designed to be flexible, as the final agreement 
will be determined on a case-by-case basis, subject to the approval of 
NUST CA, following negotiations with recruiters. Further details on terms of 
negotiation with recruitment agencies are attached as Annex “E”. The 
terms of engagement with recruiters may be reviewed on a regular basis 
and changed with the approval of the competent authority. 
b. Reward Based Referral System. The objective of the proposed Reward 
Based Referral Program is to motivate both current international students 
and alumni of NUST to recommend potential international students, thereby 
playing a role in increasing the overall international student enrollment. The 
incentives may comprise financial rewards, discounts, or other or other 
benefits as outlined by NUST. NIO will draft a dedicated Standard 
Operating Procedure (SOP) for the Reward Based Referral Program, 
which will subsequently be subject to approval from NUST's 
leadership.

16. Additional Points: 
a. English Language Requirement. For the convenience of international 
students, admission can be granted based on an English language 
certificate obtained from their previous university. 
b. HEC Scholarships and Budget Forecasting.

Annex E 
Financial Modalities of Partnering with Student Recruitment Agencies: 
i. The recruitment agencies shall be entitled to a commission of 30% of the first year’s 
tuition fee only, when a student is successfully enrolled as a full fee paying student, 
Student’s scholarship will be applicable for entire degree however, scholarships 
offered are subject to annual academic performance review. 
i. The recruitment agencies shall only be entitled to a commission of 20% and 10% of 
the first year's tuition fee for each student successfully enrolled on a 25% scholarship 
and 50% scholarship, respectively. 
ii. Recruitment agencies may nominate students with excellent academic records for 
the fee remission program, but they will not be entitled to any commission.

Nevertheless, the recruitment agent may impose a reasonable consultation fee or 
visa advisory service charge on the student.
